text: in the early hours of September 29th
2005 23 year-old Levi gassed was weaving
along Illinois his route 36 at 80 miles
per hour an Iraq war veteran he was
feeling suicidal and had taken more than
90 tablets of Tylenol and smoked some
crack before he got behind the wheel a
year before gas had returned from Iraq
while there his team conducted housing
raids on little sleep and experienced
intermittent firefights with often
unseen enemies when gas came home his
mother said he was different
he seemed more withdrawn seemed to want
to party a lot and again I didn't think
that was so strange because you know
where he'd been what he'd seen my father
was in the Korean War and he also that
was something as kids grew up knowing
you did not discuss that with him you
just so when Levi came home and didn't
discuss it I didn't push it a few months
earlier
Gast had become depressed after breaking
up with his pregnant girlfriend who he
said was unfaithful I mean it was the
kind of depression you could you could
feel it and when you got off the phone
with him you were depressed you felt it
was heavy it was dark
just after returning from Iraq and while
still on active duty
Gast had started using crack cocaine and
abusing alcohol to blot out his despair
after going AWOL for a week and failing
an army drug test
Gast was discharged and his drug problem
got worse when he returned home a
soldier is exposure to combat can cause
psychological trauma that radiates far
beyond the battlefield and to cope a
number of returning soldiers
self-medicate with alcohol or drugs
which can make them both a danger to
themselves and to the people around them
dr. Thomas Krieger a retired Navy
captain is an expert on combat trauma
clearly a red flag would be an onset of
a substance abuse problem or a worsening
of a substance abuse problem because
that causes not only worsening of the
psychological condition it causes a
disruption there social functioning can
lead to a loss of employment and can
lead to behaviors that they wouldn't
otherwise engage in and on September
29th according to prosecutors gasps
suicide attempt crossed over into
criminal territory and at 2:55 a.m.
whether it was the effects of the croc
the overdose of Tylenol the loss of
blood when he sliced his wrists the
adrenaline from the pursuit or perhaps
intentionally be vie gas slammed into a
newspaper delivery truck on the side of
the road
killing Michael Mann a married father of
four on his way to work
man's family declawed all requests to be
interviewed for this story
Levi cast was seriously injured it's not
something that I would have normally
done you know this is not something that
a rational person would do devastating I
didn't know if I was gonna be able to
walk and then I knew that I'd you know
killed this guy in the car accident and
you know yeah from what I understand he
was just driving to work that day I mean
you know it wasn't until after the
accident that gasps mother took him to
see a local mental health specialist to
get to the bottom of what was troubling
her son their diagnosis post-traumatic
stress disorder I think one of the
issues with post-traumatic stress
disorder is that it isn't necessarily
apparent to people around you or from
your own personal perspective it may not
seem like something that is worthy of
treatment in comparison to seeing
comrades who've been killed in action
but dr. Greger says the psychological
damage from PTSD is real and has been
linked to self-destructive violence by
returning soldiers the New York Times
has found 121 cases where veterans from
Iraq and Afghanistan committed a killing
after coming home from war and in about
half the cases substance abuse was
involved to the degree that someone is
heavily abusing a substance it makes it
much more difficult to treat
post-traumatic stress disorder because
you're numbing out the symptoms rather
than dealing with the symptoms and
putting them out front and trying to
understand them and come up with coping
strategies to deal with them you're
simply numbing them away but that only
lasts till the next morning and and then
you're back where you were but how does
one get back to normal when chaos and
the constant threat of death have become
everyday realities in his hometown of
Minneapolis Iraq veteran Anthony clicker
struggled with the transition home you
know you've got any months and you're
one person and you come back and you're
completely different we talked to where
you see things that we feel about your
family you don't want to be around
people you avoid people I went to a
Twins game ones here
I had to leave because there are so many
people around me that I didn't feel safe
always watching my back being angry a
lot because people didn't know I don't
believe people understood me during his
tour in Iraq clucker experienced heavy
combat on the supply convoys moving into
Baghdad they were at times crippled by
blinding sandstorms the sandstorm was
horrible the worst thing I ever been
through and I wouldn't wish it upon
anybody I couldn't see six inches to a
foot in front of me
there's firefights going off everywhere
around me during that time I expected it
to be chaos and it was chaos I was
fearful for my life but I if I would
have concentrated on that I wouldn't
have been able to do my job
as a Marine plucker was trained to
operate under intense circumstances
there's a point where I had to fire upon
a vehicle that was getting too close to
our convoy it was either me and my
Marines to die or the person that was
trying to harm us they wouldn't stop
their vehicle so I unloaded quite a bit
of rounds into the vehicle what's home
clacker continued to be haunted by the
incident and found that the decisions he
made under combat stress were hard to
explain I'm ashamed of what I did you
know sometimes but it was he was four
you know purpose then when I started
getting back to the civilian world
people wouldn't understand that saying
that to somebody kind of make them
nervous around me anxious
and troubled by nightmares clickers only
solace was alcohol my parents friends
and family you know would you telling me
you think that I'm drinking a little bit
too much or or that I shouldn't be so
angry about this or feel this way but
they didn't go through the things that I
did clucker found himself getting into
bar fights and experiencing road rage as
his drinking spiraled out of control
then on October 28th 2006 after a night
of bar-hopping clacker slammed his car
into a concrete barrier pushing it into
oncoming traffic causing an accident
that killed Deanna Casey a 16 year old
cheerleader on her way home from work
it was the most gut-wrenching thing I've
ever had to experience in my life as a
parent I still have that horrible
feeling that I failed had not been able
to protect my child officers at the
scene Zach lick her stank of alcohol and
arrested him Brock hunter a Minnesota
lawyer and an army vet has actively
defended numerous vets who have gotten
into trouble he immediately suspected
Anthony was suffering from the effects
of combat trauma within a minute of
talking to him it was quite obvious that
he was a veteran who was in some
significant psychological distress the
thousand-yard stare that is so often
referred to a level of tension in his
body language that was impossible to
miss the first time we went to court one
as is when I learned that mr. clucker
was a veteran and that he was telling
his attorney that he was suffering from
post-traumatic stress as a police
officer myself I've had to see bad
horrible things you could say that I've
suffered from post-traumatic stress so
my reaction was well mr. clubber suck it
up like the rest of us have
it doesn't give you an excuse to go out
and drink in excess get behind the wheel
and drive a vehicle that then kills
another human being could the
destructive actions of returning
soldiers like Levi gasp and Anthony
clicker have been prevented dr. Greger
says there's no simple answer one of the
issues is that many individuals don't
initially recognize it as being a
problem until they've had it for a
period of time or they're reluctant to
seek mental health care because they
talked to friends that were deployed and
they're not reporting similar symptoms
very common for people even though we
screened for post-traumatic stress
disorder depression substance abuse and
possible violence among all soldiers
returning from deployment many of them
do not endorse that they're having those
symptoms or concerned about those
problems or that they need treatment
even though it's causing horrible
disruptions and problems with their
lives but addressing those needs is an
uphill battle especially for a military
mental health system that a pentagon
Task Force says is overburden
understaffed short on funds and
undermined by the stigma attached to
PTSD so it was there it was offered but
I think there's a stigmatism still that
goes with that going to get help
especially when you're in the Marine
Corps
Anthony clicker pled guilty to vehicular
homicide and wrote a letter of apology
to Deanna Casey's family I felt that he
knew that he had a problem he wanted to
change his behavior and I don't believe
that he chose that night to get in the
car and say I'm gonna kill somebody so
do I think he's a bad person no I think
he made some really bad
both the judge and the victim's family
decided that clucker needed counseling
not jail time he was given an unusual
sentence that combined probation with
intensive treatment at the VA facility
and community service Anthony was
clearly in distress and clearly dealing
with the haunting memories of the war we
sent them to this war if they came home
with an injury to their psyche from that
war that had a direct bearing and them
getting into trouble with the law I do
think that we owe them the benefit of
the doubt on some level but the courts
are still sorting out how to handle
returning vets who commit crimes a life
is also lost when Levi's gas got behind
the wheel but the outcome of this case
couldn't have been more different than
Anthony clickers five months after the
car crash that killed Michael Mann gas
thought he would face a manslaughter
charge it was a Friday February 24th of
2006 my lawyer called and said you know
we need to go turn yourself in and I was
counting they're charging you with
first-degree murder I was like whoa you
know that I almost knocked me off my
feet I couldn't believe it at his bench
trial the victim's wife wrote that she
quote had feelings of hate towards Levi
ghast
for his role in her husband's death in
the end the judge ruled that gas had
intentionally tried to kill himself by
ramming into Michael man's pickup truck
Gast is currently serving a 25 year
sentence for first-degree murder at a
maximum-security prison in southern
Illinois it's very hard to deal with
especially being in here you know every
day I think you know how I'm in here for
first-degree murder with all these other
guys that have actually shot somebody or
because somebody up you know that's just
not me gas says his lawyer who dealt
mostly with DUI cases hardly mentioned
his war experience or the possibility
that he was having difficulties because
of it my lawyer didn't really come into
play you know I figured it would have
and like I said this is my first time
ever really being in trouble so I
figured he knew what he was doing my
lawyer had talked me out of taking a
jury trial which i think was a huge
mistake I think a jury would have seen
it differently and hopefully I can get
back into court
Gast is appealing his sentence yes
mother believes that the military led
her son down when the army discovered he
had a drug problem while still on active
duty the army did not treat his
addiction and he was discharged the
military really does have a
zero-tolerance for drug abuse so it's
sort of a double punishment you're being
discharged
even though he may have been previously
a good soldier or marine and you're
going to be denied care for the disorder
that you wouldn't have had but for your
service to your country I think that
what happened that night started the day
they let him out knowing that he had a
serious drug issue it's like they threw
him out in the world and said you're on
your own and you know and it's kind like
telling the world well sorry we put this
guy back out there you just deal with it
the best way you know how I'm angry I'm
angry they owed him more than that you
know nobody made him go to Iraq he did
that because he wanted to serve his
country he wanted to do something good
he wanted his life to mean something and
when he comes back and he's got issues
because of what happened and they're
just they're done with me
